dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: A lot of people will see you as somebody who's drank in harmony their whole life. They've seen so much harmony, heard so much harmony. How do you make the choices, there's so much that's possible when you know stuff. How do you have the courage to make a choice?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: It comes from just your life experience. And that moves you in a certain direction. How it gets expressed, many times, is sudden. Complete surprise. (laughs)

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, yeah, yeah. I find it fascinating in music to think about, you know, say I arrive in a place, if I'm going, say I'm going to D flat major. And there's something you once taught me. You taught me this song Don't Follow the Crowd.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Oh, yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And there's that chord. It's not a Dennerman chord, but it functions as a dominant chord. But it doesn't matter, because you're still going to the place you're going to.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Right, right, right.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: It's something like, um... (keyboard music)

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Right, right, right, right.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah. So this chord being, like a major seven with a sharp five, and a natural, like, there's no dominant thing.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Right, right.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: But at that moment, I'm coming from here, and I wanna forge some, some solution. I get myself in a situation. (keyboard music)

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah. Right.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: That haunted me for days.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: (Herbie laughs)

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: 'Cause, you know, I just wouldn't think to use that chord in that situation. And there it was! And, you know, if you read the rule book, it's, that not in it.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, and this is what I learned from the great Chris Anderson.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Chris Anderson, yeah, yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: The idea of going to a D flat chord. Normally it does a dominant like the A flat seven. But back in the 20s, they also used to do things like, (keyboard music)

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Oh yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: So, It's always coming. (keyboard music) Coming from just below the key. From C with a seventh. And when we don't normally say a C seventh and an A flat seventh are related, you know, 'cause so many of the notes are different. You've got this, and you've got a G--

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Exactly right, it gets gnarly right?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, right.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah. But if you verse that correctly, then you're safe.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Oh yeah, you can get all of those notes.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: You can get away with it.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah. (laughs) The other thing that I like, that we both do on occasion, is to be on the chord we want to arrive at with the bottom part of our structure. And the chord before the arrival chord, to have that on top.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah. Oh yeah. (keyboard music)

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Right, right, right.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Something like that. And that's not 'cause like emotionally, it's almost like I'm here, I'm arriving here. But, if the base note is the same, it's like this inevitability about it, it's like I was there all along.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: And it makes like a pull.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, yeah. It's like one thing is moving in one direction and one thing has arrived, so it's this tension and it's glorious. I love thinking about these things emotionally, just because that's a feeling, I know that feeling in my life.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Music is not different from life.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: (Jacob) No.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: You know, and I think that's probably the greatest attraction to those of us who play music.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah. Was there ever a point in your life when you were younger where you felt like you had consistently fell back into the same habits?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: You'd find, man,

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I don't want to play this same thing again.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I had a really great experience when I was working with Miles Davis. I felt like I was in a rut playing the same stuff, and I was getting depressed because of it. And Myles said something to me. I thought he said, Don't play the butter notes. And so, I thought, what did he mean by that?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So you thought he said butter.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Butter notes, right.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And he said bottom. But you thought he said butter.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Wow.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: And so, I started thinking, oh great, what could butter be? What is butter? Then I started thinking, what are the obvious notes? For example in a chord. The obvious notes are the third and the seventh. So I said, maybe if I leave those out. It changed everything for me, from that moment on. I got more applause for that solo than I did the whole week. (Herbie laughs)

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Wow.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I wouldn't play the voice things I play today if that had not happened.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: That's amazing.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I've been using this tune Amazing Grace.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Oh, right.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And so, we could play a bit of that if you want to. And we could talk about some stuff. I've been doing it in F. (keyboards playing Amazing Grace) (laughing) Thanks Herbie, that was a trip.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, thank you.
